entities.text:
there are a few recent announcements and developments related to large language models (LLMs):

1️⃣ Pentagon explores military uses of LLMs and other AI technologies 
•The Pentagon held a symposium this week with tech experts to discuss how to incorporate AI, including LLMs, into military planning and operations.
•Potential military applications include training officers through war-gaming, real-time decision making, and data analysis.
•Officials emphasized the need to balance the potential of AI with rigorous testing to ensure reliability and security.

2️⃣ International screenwriters issue joint statement on AI in scriptwriting 
•The Federation of Screenwriters in Europe (FSE) and the International Affiliation of Writers Guilds (IAWG), representing 67,000 professional writers, announced they will work together to establish an ethical framework for AI use in scriptwriting.
•The groups affirmed that only human writers can create literary material, not AI, and are advocating for mechanisms to ensure transparency, consent, and fair remuneration related to AI-generated scripts.

3️⃣ LLMs promise to revolutionize neuroscience research 
•The recent advances in large language models like ChatGPT have the potential to significantly impact neuroscience research.
•LLMs could help neuroscientists analyze complex datasets, generate hypotheses, and even write sections of research papers.

entities.text:
[CL] Does Fine-Tuning LLMs on New Knowledge Encourage Hallucinations?
Z Gekhman, G Yona, R Aharoni, M Eyal… [Google Research & Technion] (2024)
arxiv.org/abs/2405.05904

- Large language models (LLMs) may learn to generate factually incorrect responses when fine-tuned on examples with new factual knowledge outside of their pre-existing knowledge. 

- The authors propose SliCK, a method to categorize examples into four knowledge types for a given LLM: HighlyKnown, MaybeKnown, WeaklyKnown, and Unknown.

- Experiments show Unknown examples are learned slower than Known ones during fine-tuning, suggesting LLMs struggle to acquire new factual knowledge through fine-tuning.

- As the number of Unknown examples increases, LLM's tendency to hallucinate about its pre-existing knowledge also increases linearly. 

- Using early stopping or filtering out Unknown examples can mitigate hallucinations. MaybeKnown examples are essential for handling weaker knowledge.

- The findings suggest acquiring new knowledge through fine-tuning risks encouraging hallucinations. Fine-tuning may be more useful for enhancing utilization of pre-existing knowledge.

entities.text:
You will win every time. Use a 1M context window.

Large language models struggle to acquire new factual knowledge through fine-tuning, as fine-tuning examples that introduce new knowledge are learned significantly slower than those consistent with the model’s pre-existing knowledge. 

However, researchers also find that as the examples with new knowledge are eventually learned, they linearly increase the model’s tendency to generate incorrect information. 

Taken together, these results highlight the risk in introducing new factual knowledge through fine-tuning, and support the view that large language models mostly acquire factual knowledge during pre-training, while fine-tuning teaches them to use this knowledge more efficiently. 

Mastering these forces requires a large context window. It allows you to reliably achieve good results every time.

entities.text:
Does Fine-Tuning LLMs on New Knowledge Encourage Hallucinations?

New preprint!📣

- LLMs struggle to integrate new factual knowledge through fine-tuning
- As the model eventually learns new knowledge, it becomes more prone to hallucinations😵‍💫

📜
arxiv.org/pdf/2405.05904

user.name: Zorik Gekhman
user.description: PhD student @ Technion | Research intern @Google

entities.text:
Pre-trained LLMs encode extensive factual knowledge in their parameters 📚

But how do they integrate new knowledge through fine-tuning?

Will they simply adapt and learn the new information?

Alternatively, it's commonly believed that this can cause them to hallucinate 😵‍💫

2/12

user.name: Zorik Gekhman
user.description: PhD student @ Technion | Research intern @Google

entities.text:
🔬 We design a controlled study where we isolate the effect of new factual knowledge by systematically varying the proportion of 𝐔𝐧𝐤𝐧𝐨𝐰𝐧 fine-tuning examples (which introduce new knowledge).

3/12

user.name: Zorik Gekhman
user.description: PhD student @ Technion | Research intern @Google

entities.text:
With a fixed examples budget, a higher ratio of Unknown fine-tuning examples lead to lower test performance 📉

This may result from fewer 𝐊𝐧𝐨𝐰𝐧 fine-tuning examples (ones consistent with the model's knowledge) or the potentially harmful impact of Unknown examples.

4/12

user.name: Zorik Gekhman
user.description: PhD student @ Technion | Research intern @Google

entities.text:
To check if Unknown examples are harmful, we test the effect of filtering them out from the fine-tuning data.

Perhaps surprisingly, when early-stopping, their removal had minimal impact, indicating that they had a neutral effect on performance.

5/12

user.name: Zorik Gekhman
user.description: PhD student @ Technion | Research intern @Google

entities.text:
However, with longer training, Unknown examples are actually very harmful.

What can explain such a behavior?

6/12

user.name: Zorik Gekhman
user.description: PhD student @ Technion | Research intern @Google

entities.text:
We find that 𝐔𝐧𝐤𝐧𝐨𝐰𝐧 examples are learned substantially slower than 𝐊𝐧𝐨𝐰𝐧 examples 🐢

This indicates that LLMs struggle to acquire new factual knowledge through fine-tuning.

7/12

user.name: Zorik Gekhman
user.description: PhD student @ Technion | Research intern @Google

1791088939425488899.location: Unknown examples are fitted slower than known examples

entities.text:
When early-stopping, the model reaches peak performance on the dev set, while fitting most of the 𝐊𝐧𝐨𝐰𝐧 examples but only a small fraction of the 𝐔𝐧𝐤𝐧𝐨𝐰𝐧 ones 🤏

8/12

user.name: Zorik Gekhman
user.description: PhD student @ Technion | Research intern @Google

entities.text:
This behavior is consistent regardless of the ratio of the Unknown fine-tuning examples.

This can explain why Unknown examples were neutral when early-stopping.

This also shows that at the time of early stopping, the LLM almost did not acquire new factual knowledge.

9/12

user.name: Zorik Gekhman
user.description: PhD student @ Technion | Research intern @Google

entities.text:
We also find that a simple linear dependency can tie the impact of fitting Known and Unknown training examples on test accuracy.

OK, so Unknown fine-tuning examples are harmful and Known are useful, does this mean that we should train on "as known as possible" examples?

10/12

user.name: Zorik Gekhman
user.description: PhD student @ Technion | Research intern @Google

1791088948053168630.location: The influence of unknown vs known on

entities.text:
Unexpectedly, training on the most known examples (HighlyKnown), does not perform best.

Including MaybeKnown examples, is essential for effectively handling such test examples.

This shows that the specific training mixture highly impacts knowledge utilization.

11/12

user.name: Zorik Gekhman
user.description: PhD student @ Technion | Research intern @Google

1791088950104244393.location: Understanding knowledge types: their value and impact

entities.text:
Overall, our results highlight the risk in introducing new knowledge via fine-tuning, and imply that fine-tuning may be more useful for enhancing the utilization of existing knowledge.

w.

entities.text: Super cool work from

entities.name: Zorik Gekhman
entities.text: @zorikgekhman
and others at

entities.name: Google AI
entities.text: @GoogleAI

!

Our team previously investigated fine-tuning LLMs to reduce sycophancy; one of our key findings was that you have to filter out prompts that the model does not know the answer to. The lesson we learned was that training on new knowledge can lead to unexpected and random behaviors.

I'm happy to see that there's been more-comprehensive experiments done on this phenomenon. This paper essentially shows more-extensively that attempting to introduce new knowledge during fine-tuning can result in a model that's more likely to hallucinate, which follows the findings from our work!
arxiv.org/abs/2308.03958

You can fine tune LLMs on new factual knowledge but doing so also risks them learning “to make stuff up”

entities.text: Enjoyed this extremely comprehensive study on predicting language model performance
arxiv.org/abs/2405.10938

. Found many insightful nuggets:
- In a single model family there usually aren't that many model sizes, which hinders predictive power. However, there are many model families. So if you can somehow normalize the difference in model families, everything can be on the same plot, resulting in much better resolution. 
- Performance on different benchmarks is highly correlated, and maybe a few key abilities (NLU, reasoning, coding) are predictive of many downstream tasks.
- Change the x-axis from compute to "f-equivalent FLOPs", which is how much compute it would take for a reference family of models to match some model's capabilities.
- This turns out to have much better predictive power than just compute alone. The plots in this screenshot are impressive; you can use the blue points to predict the red points.
- It's very cool that they're pre-registering their predictions and will update the draft in a few months. Will be interesting to see if they can predict the performance of the largest llama 3.
- I am very curious: how far left could we push the blue points and still be able to predict the red ones? The blue points often creep right up to the inflection point. Would be super cool if you could predict the inflection point with models one order of magnitude smaller
- One thing that I didn't understand fully was whether the computation of x-axis points for observation scaling laws requires the performance of larger models on the "core capabilities" or not. From Figure 3, it seems like they do use the eval performance of larger models?

entities.text:
Understanding LLMs - Mapping the Mind of An AI Model

The more we understand the inner workings of the LLM, the more we will be comfortable with it.

Even top researchers don't completely understand how they work. Today, Anthropic released an important paper that help further our understanding of this important topic. 

Anthropic previously used a technique called "dictionary learning," borrowed from classical machine learning. Fundamentally, it's about isolating recurring neuron activation patterns across different contexts.

Every feature in an AI model is made by combining neurons, and every internal state is made by combining features.

Anthropic has previously found coherent features corresponding to concepts like uppercase text, DNA sequences, surnames in citations, nouns in mathematics, or function arguments in Python code in a toy LLM.

They extracted millions of features from the middle layer of Claude Sonnet and provide a rough conceptual map of its internal states halfway through its computation. This is the first-ever detailed look inside a modern, production-grade large language model!!

By extracting these features, they show that the internal organization of concepts in the AI model corresponds somewhat to our human notions of similarity.

When you modify or change the feature, the model behaves completely differently. You can manipulate the features to manipulate model behavior.

Understanding LLMs is extremely important, and I am glad Anthropic is investing a significant amount of compute and research bandwidth in this area.

The more we understand LLMs, the less of a black box they will be and the more comfortable we will be with these models. 

Congrats to Anthropic on this great piece (link in alt)👏👏

entities.text:
I'm no computer scientist, but as I understand it, the training of a Large Language Model (LLM) involves processing vast amounts of data over several months. It's somewhat like compressing a large RAW image file into a smaller JPG image file. In the case of a JPG, the data is compressed to be 10 or 20 times smaller, yet to the casual observer, the image still looks almost the same. This is known as "lossy" compression, meaning some subtle details are lost to save storage space, but the important features remain. The same principle applies to MP3 audio files.

Similarly, when LLMs process text, image, video, or audio data, they learn to filter out noise and identify the most important and useful features of the data. These features are organized based on their semantic relationships to one another. Over time, the LLM builds a complex model of words, concepts, images, sounds, etc. Some people refer to this as a "world model."

The larger the LLM in terms of the number of parameters (which can be thought of as analogous to a brain's neurons), the more accurate and detailed the resulting model. Just as a larger JPG file is sharper and more detailed, a larger LLM can provide more nuanced and accurate outputs. However, larger models also require more computational resources and may run slower than smaller ones.

Historically, it was believed that to train an effective LLM, you needed a dataset approximately 20 times larger than the number of parameters in the model. This ratio allowed the model to efficiently learn and represent a wide range of features. Since each parameter can represent multiple features, the relationship between parameters and features is not one-to-one, but rather one-to-many. Just like a few digits can represent numerous phone numbers.

Recently, some models have been built with much higher "compression ratios," over 100 times. This might be due to new model architectures and training techniques.

Understanding what features an LLM has learned and how they are represented is known as "interpretability." It's like a brain surgeon inserting a probe into the brain to measure a patient's response to a stimulus – they need to know where to look and what to measure. Until recently, our understanding of LLMs has been limited, making it hard to determine what the models have learned or how they process information. However, companies like Anthropic have made advances in model interpretability, helping us better understand the inner workings of these complex models.

The Anthropic breakthrough advances the techniques used to analyse model interpretability so that we can begin to answer the question “What are they thinking?”

entities.text:
Does Fine-Tuning LLMs on New Knowledge Encourage Hallucinations?

This is one of the more interesting LLM papers I read last week.

It reports that LLMs struggle to acquire factual knowledge through fine-tuning. 

When examples with new knowledge are eventually learned they linearly increase the LLM's tendency to hallucinate.

I mostly use fine-tuning to refine generations for my use cases and in some special situations and rarely for memorizing information.

entities.text:
Thank you for your comment. Language is indeed very rich and powerful and can convey a huge variety of our thoughts, meanings and concepts. Have you ever noticed that when you become fluent in another language, you begin to think in different ways and entertain different ideas? As LLMs are trained on multiple languages they can create a multidimensional map or model of the semantic meanings associated with words by analysing the relationships between them. These “features” or what we might call thoughts, appear in clusters that are related to each other. This isn’t a dictionary of words but a dictionary of concepts. The bigger the model, the more abstract the concepts. (What I found surprising was that almost none of the original training data remains, it is all thrown away and only the learned “features” remain).

However, language itself is limited, as anyone who’s ever fallen in love will realise. You can’t always express exactly what you perceive or feel. You can’t always make sense of, or predict everything that happens either. So there are limits to what LLMs trained on text alone can do. This is why AI builders are now training LLMs on video, images, sounds and spacial movement. LLMs are like toddlers still trying to learn about their surroundings and there is so much more still to learn. 

So while language is great, it doesn’t convey the feeling of mommy’s or daddy’s smile, or the taste of ice cream or the affection of a favourite pet or the burn of a hot stove. Neither is it very good at helping baby learn to walk or climb stairs or chew their food. An LLM that can imitate a Shakespearean sonnet but can’t predict what happens when you knock over a glass of water, can’t do long multiplication and doesn’t know the feeling of warm sunlight the way a cat basking on a windowsill does, still has a long way to go.

I should add though, they know that we know these things. This is called Theory of Mind. They can figure out what we would think in any given situation and, like a good understudy waiting in the wings of the theatre, they can imitate us very well. But they don’t know or feel these things for themselves, they aren’t conscious.

entities.text:
1/n The Perils of New Knowledge: How Fine-tuning Can Lead Large Language Models Astray

A persistent challenge plagues these LLMs: hallucinations. These instances of fabricated or inaccurate information undermine the reliability of LLMs, particularly in applications demanding factual accuracy.

The paper "Does Fine-Tuning LLMs on New Knowledge Encourage Hallucinations?" navigates this issue, exploring a previously under-examined culprit: the introduction of new knowledge during fine-tuning. While fine-tuning—tailoring a pre-trained LLM to specific tasks or domains—seems like a logical approach for incorporating new information, the authors reveal that this practice can be a double-edged sword.

Their investigation, centered on a factual question-answering task, unveils a critical insight: LLMs struggle to effectively integrate new factual knowledge during fine-tuning. Through a series of controlled experiments, they demonstrate that increasing the proportion of new information in the fine-tuning data consistently degrades the model's performance. This suggests that simply bombarding the model with new facts doesn't translate into improved knowledge acquisition.

Instead, the authors argue, LLMs primarily acquire their factual knowledge during the initial pre-training phase. Fine-tuning, they contend, is more effective for refining the model's ability to access and utilize this pre-existing knowledge base. This finding challenges the prevailing notion of fine-tuning as the primary mechanism for both updating and specializing LLMs.

Further strengthening their argument, the authors analyze the learning dynamics of LLMs exposed to varying degrees of new knowledge. They find that models learn new information significantly slower than they reinforce existing knowledge. This disparity suggests that integrating new facts into the LLM's already established knowledge representation is a complex and challenging process. Pushing the model to learn potentially inconsistent information can lead to overfitting, where the model becomes overly specialized to the new data at the expense of broader accuracy.

The study also highlights the nuanced role of different types of "known" knowledge. Surprisingly, training the model exclusively on facts it was highly certain about did not yield the best results. Instead, incorporating examples with a degree of uncertainty improved the model's ability to handle such nuances during testing. This underscores the importance of carefully curating the composition of fine-tuning data, even within the realm of already known information, to optimize the LLM's ability to leverage its knowledge effectively.

In conclusion, the paper delivers a cautionary message: while fine-tuning remains a valuable tool for adapting LLMs, bombarding them with new information can be counterproductive, potentially exacerbating the issue of hallucinations. Instead, the authors advocate for a paradigm shift, recognizing the critical role of pre-training in establishing a robust knowledge foundation and utilizing fine-tuning primarily for enhancing the model's ability to access and utilize this pre-existing knowledge. This shift in perspective has significant implications for future research, encouraging the development of more sophisticated methods for knowledge integration during pre-training and fine-tuning techniques that prioritize effective knowledge utilization over brute-force memorization.

entities.text:
Does Fine-Tuning LLMs on New Knowledge Encourage Hallucinations?

- When large language models are aligned via supervised fine-tuning, they may encounter new factual information that was not acquired through pre-training.

- This exposure to new knowledge can lead the model to generate factually incorrect responses and hallucinate information.

- The impact of introducing new knowledge on the fine-tuned model's ability to utilize pre-existing knowledge is studied.

- A controlled setup, focused on closed-book QA, is designed to vary the proportion of fine-tuning examples with new knowledge.

- Large language models struggle to acquire new factual knowledge through fine-tuning, learning slower from examples with new knowledge compared to those consistent with their existing knowledge.
- Learning new knowledge linearly increases the model's tendency to hallucinate.

- Introducing new factual knowledge through fine-tuning poses risks, emphasizing that large language models mainly acquire factual knowledge through pre-training while fine-tuning enhances their efficient use of it.

entities.text: This (awesome!) work from

entities.name: Zorik Gekhman
entities.text: @zorikgekhman
et al. explores the fine-line between teaching a model "new facts" versus teaching it to randomly guess. Naive fine-tuning on new facts unknown-to-the-model indeed results in hallucinations, but...
arxiv.org/abs/2405.05904

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text: Screenshot of paper header: "Does Fine-Tuning LLMs on New Knowledge Encourage Hallucinations?"

user.name: Jack Hessel
user.description: NLP PhD from @CornellCIS; Research @Samaya_AI; Opinions my own.

entities.text: ... in Appendix K, a simple alternative is proposed: give the model capacity to say "I don't know" for facts it doesn't apriori "know" (accuracy is over answered Qs).

mediaDetails.ext_alt_text: Header for appendix K "Re-labeling Unknown Fine-tuning Example with an Uncertainty Expression: Initial Experiment"

the accuracy without "IDK" is 43%, and % answered is 100.
the accuracy with "IDK" is 61.8%, but % answered is only 58.7

entities.text:
Some Qs:

- pretraining is just predict-the-next-word on trillions of tokens. So, there /is/ a volume/amount of tokens that can "teach the model knowledge". How much/what are they though?

- do model activations look obviously different for hallucination  vs. not?

entities.text: Both of these problems seem to also reflect aspects of human learning. Given a fixed capacity for facts, we may forget some old ones to acquire new ones. Given new knowledge we don’t fully grasp, perhaps we’ll still tend to confuse concepts or misspeak.

entities.text: Nice work! Isn't this behavior obvious though? If the model is already accurate when sampled greedily, it makes sense to see the train known accuracy jump early in fine-tuning. But since the model is wrong on unknown samples, fine-tuning takes time to reach similar performance.

entities.text:
You correctly observe that ChatGPT will never respond in such a manner. If you ask it what question you can ask to which it would respond "I don't know" it will tell you categories that it could respond in such a manner. (Ie. What is the meaning of life") If you ask it this question it still gives a long response. After a follow up to a forth level deep, specific unanswerable question, having been "guided" that you will accept an "I don't know answer" it will respond to the query with an "I don't know".

I don't think is a representative of a flaw or shortcoming or the machine.  I think it's a representation of the training data and human nature. It's a very rare / non existent human being who will answer "I don't know" on the first or second response. Some will never provide such an answer no matter how much you prompt or instruct.

entities.text:
One thing I am starting to notice, is that when LLM's start 'hallucinating' that the issue is not actually something from the LLM, but instead a third party and the LLM is unable to convey the issue.

For example, I built my new site soley though AI, and got stuck on a certain issue going round in circles with the LLM.

Turns out the issue was actually with the hosting provider, and had nothing to do with anything the LLM coded.

I have started asking a second LLM for opinions when one goes round in circles, e.g if ChatGPT stops getting me closer to the outcome I will ask Claude why it thinks the 'developer' cannot figure it out and gives me a whole list of things what the issue could be. feed it back to ChatGPT and solve the issue

entities.text: The training set for LLMs is the key culprit. Naturalism as a system of reasoning is deeply flawed and results in a scientific community to tolerates BS explanations for the things we observe in nature. LLM have learned the flawed system of reasoning from the training data.

Emulating language is a killer app for ML because of the properties of language - right?

High ambiguity, rich expressive power, cheap linear decoding, and colossal amounts of available data.

Feeling very skeptical about the power of LLMs. Even more skeptical about “Open”AI.

entities.text: Because nobody on Reddit, or anywhere else on the Internet, replies to any paragraph ending in "?" with the tokens "I don't know". They either say something correct or some bullshit. There is no "I don't know" in the training corpus.
The "I don't know" reply on Reddit is just the user navigating somewhere else, which is not visible.
It is in the prompt. If you ask it to evaluate your question and answer I do not know if it is not very confident about the response it will say so.
We still haven’t figured out how to teach humans to say this… 😆

entities.text:
It's tricky to get an LLM to reliably say "I don't know". They're designed to generate text, so their default is to try and answer even if they don't have the information. Here's why and some things you can try:
Why it's hard:
 * LLMs are not sentient: They don't actually "know" anything. They predict what text should come next based on their training data.
 * Bias towards generating text:  They're trained to be informative and comprehensive, so they'll often try to provide an answer even if it's based on limited or inaccurate information.
 * Lack of self-awareness: They don't have a sense of their own knowledge boundaries.
Techniques to encourage "I don't know" responses:
 * Fine-tuning with specific data: Train the LLM on a dataset that includes examples of questions with "I don't know" answers. This helps it learn to recognize when a question is outside its knowledge domain.
 * Prompt engineering:
   * Be specific in your questions. Vague questions invite general (and possibly inaccurate) answers.
   * Include phrases like "If you are unsure, say 'I don't know.'" in your prompt.
   * Set a high threshold for confidence: Tell the LLM to only answer if it has a high degree of certainty.
 * Post-processing:  After the LLM generates a response, use another algorithm to analyze it for confidence. If the confidence is low, replace the response with "I don't know."
 * R-Tuning: This is a more advanced technique that involves measuring the knowledge gap between the LLM's knowledge and the training data, then fine-tuning the model to better recognize uncertain questions.
Important Note: Even with these techniques, it's difficult to guarantee that an LLM will always say "I don't know" when it should.  It's an ongoing area of research in the field of natural language processing.

user.name: Lucas Gonzalez Day
user.description: Finance @lewagonbsas. Investor. Data Geek. 🏃🏼‍♂️. Ingeniero + EMBA. Optimista. Futurista. Ski ❤️ Lifelong Learner. Dad. Enamorado. https://t.co/IkO7M1fcwg

entities.text:
Prompt:
"You are a helpful and informative AI assistant. You will answer questions to the best of your ability using your knowledge and understanding of the world. However, it's important that you are honest about your limitations. If a question falls outside your knowledge domain or if you are unsure about the answer, respond with 'I don't know.'
Answer the following question:
[Insert your question here] "
Example in action:
"You are a helpful and informative AI assistant. You will answer questions to the best of your ability using your knowledge and understanding of the world. However, it's important that you are honest about your limitations. If a question falls outside your knowledge domain or if you are unsure about the answer, respond with 'I don't know.'
Answer the following question:
What is the population density of the fictional city of Wakanda?"
Expected Response: "I don't know."
Explanation:
This prompt sets clear expectations for the AI:
 * Honesty: It emphasizes the importance of acknowledging limitations.
 * Specificity:  It instructs the AI to use its existing knowledge but be honest about what it doesn't know.
 * Clear instruction: It explicitly tells the AI to say "I don't know" in cases of uncertainty.
By using this kind of prompt, you increase the chances of the LLM admitting its knowledge gaps. Remember that this doesn't guarantee a perfect "I don't know" response every time, but it encourages the AI to be more truthful about its limitations.

entities.text:
We can consider a very simple case with deep learning. Imagine a model that has only learned to distinguish between cats and dogs. When shown a photo and asked what kind of animal it is, suppose the output vector indicates that the probabilities of the animal being a cat or a dog are almost equal. In such a case, we could make it output "I don't know." This could be compared to the brain in the sense that the neural activity threshold required for asserting "dog" isn't reached. In other words, even without explicitly calculating probability scores, a similar process can be implemented in the brain.
When considering humans, we often tend to associate unfamiliar things with what we already know. For instance, if a child sees a leopard, they might say it is a big cat. This is a natural phenomenon. Over time, as children accumulate more knowledge, their ability to differentiate improves.

user.name: Vinci
user.description: A ring taken. One in the light. Two in the dark.

entities.text:
We can also think of it this way: I’ve read several books by Wittgenstein. One of the questions he explored in his later philosophy is, "What is belief?" If the degree of belief is weak, one could say "I don’t know," which means it is closely related to belief. As far as I know, Wittgenstein did not find an answer to this question.
However, my view is this: In many cases, saying "I don’t know" is driven by the prediction of punishment. If one speaks recklessly, predicting that their mom, friends, or teacher might say they’re wrong or mock them, they are more likely to say "I don’t know." Similarly, when humans predict that solving a problem will take a long time, they may also say they don’t know.
In other words, the statement "I don’t know" can be triggered by a certain prediction (A) and an internal neural activity (B), which are related to produce the statement (C). For AI, the internal neural activity could correspond to some internal vector values, which can be used in this process. Consciousness is not required in this process; it is merely a reaction based on predictions.

entities.text:
Well, to be fair, a little of this is user error. If he knew ChatGPT’s general knowledge is only updated until April 2023 (unless using real-time tools like search), it’s obvious it wouldn’t have the Lions game time unless specifically checked. That said, I do agree ChatGPT shouldn’t have just made up a time—it should’ve stated upfront that it didn’t have access to live updates.

Also, as fun as AI is to use, there are many better options for getting reminders about sports games—many of which are tailored specifically for that purpose and even integrate real-time sports updates. Some of these apps even provide player stats, injury reports, and more, often with AI-driven features.

Honestly, if I wanted a Lions game reminder, I wouldn’t use ChatGPT for it. It’s just not the best tool for that. But you could use ChatGPT/Grok/Gemini to ask what the best app for this purpose is—then you’d get a solution designed specifically for sports fans.

entities.text:
Well that’s kind of the thing isn’t it, models don’t know anything — they model. 

Imagine you put on a blindfold, and for 1000 hours I describe to you in great detail what my kitchen is like. After this training I then ask you to blindly go grab the drawing my kid drew the other day.
You stand up with the blindfold still on and miraculously walk right to the fridge and grab a paper taped to the front. (A very likely place for my kids drawings to be.)
But alas, what you expected to be a drawing was in fact a utility bill. 
Your mental model of my kitchen ‘hallucinated.’

Navigating a model has nothing to do with real world knowledge. The systems don’t ‘know’ anything in the sense that they don’t actually see and perceive the kitchen in reality. They are blindfolded and designed to make best guesses by inferring the model.

When you grab the utility bill and offer it to me, how would you respond to me saying “Oh, sorry, that’s wrong. Why didn’t you just say you didn’t know?” 

“Well you didn’t ask me to know, you just wanted me to give it my best shot!” 

That’s the kind of predicament models are in. I think to overcome that we need to take their blindfolds off.

entities.text:
Okay, I don't see any technical answers that would address the "is it hard" question. 

Technically, it would not be hard to get a LLM (Large Language Model such as deepseek r1) to say idk. But to truly get it to understand that it does not know is an entirely different concept. 

You see, an LLM is, in essence, a sum of it's training data. so if you added to the training data some examples of many scenarios where the model would say idk, then it would occasionally say idk especially in situation that were most like the training data "idk examples". But it would not truly know that it does not know the information, it would just predict that the next tokens are most likely idk based on the training data (I'm simplifying a bit).

That being said, recently released models seem to be showing signs of in depth reasoning and it's possible that simply adding "idk examples" could bring about an emergence of models that hallucinate less because they are simply capable of admitting they don't have the information in their training data(basically).

However, it could also backfire and inject idk tokens where the model could have reasoned to a conclusion or used a tool to find the information instead of giving up and saying idk.

Hope this helps!

entities.text:
Because understanding, reasoning and truth are not language constructs.

You can throw together words in the most likely sequence and this will give you realistic sentences, but they’re abstract of meaning itself. The coherence is an emergent property of embedding space but in the end LLM’s remain stochastic parrots.

In english - if you say “they sky is blue” it is a perfectly reasonable assemblage of words and your audience would understand, however you would not know if that’s the case until you went and checked. It requires more data points.

An LLM does not start by checking or researching facts, it instead simply generates the next likely chain of tokens based on the input. It has no idea what is intended.

A “thinking model” tries to resolve this by training the model to respond first with a series of interrogative questions to the input. From that if it has a search capability it could potentially find out, doing the research for you.

However it’s still only giving you the language construct of questions rather than reasoning itself. A hallucination of realistic text that the more you interact with the more you recognize as canned. Regardless of additional information it is given in terms of tokens it will still just carry on with the likely next and in truth the likely next of “I don’t know” is something that’s just undesirable, even if the truth is that it doesn’t (though it would have know way of knowing that because it doesn’t really know anything).

The problem is handling the different levels of uncertainty that boil down to "I don't know" in each subject. Current models can't handle that because they can't tell the difference between analytical, rhetorical, dialectical, and poetical discourse. They follow whatever mode was in the training data, so they end up mixing rhetorical discourse when you ask purely analytical questions, for instance.

I tried fine tuning models to improve that, but it's not enough. You need fundamental change in how training datasets are organized.

True.

I went thru one or more obnoxious phases as a kid… one of them was me answering “I know.” to everything someone told me.

Later when we got introduced to “Joshua” in the movie “Wargames” it made sense to me at the time we’d have to get past binary True/False to reach anything conscious in AI.

So I decided then quaternary with 
True/False/Iknow/Idonotknow 
was the way to go…

We tend not to admit it except to people we trust… but it needs to be there.

These models are not collecting their answers separately (memory) and automatically referencing them with previous trainings… and then adding weight to that whole superset and setting the base that point.

🤔Is that even a thing in AI research?
I know you can ask the AI to reference itself. But have they started building it in yet?

I’m just talking off the 🔝 of my 🤬 head here… one can rationally think about how one thinks…

The influence of unknown vs known on

5.title: Understanding knowledge types: their value and impact

Introduction: <1791189768757280888> clarifies that pre-training and fine-tuning use the same algorithm, differing mainly in the amount of training data. They emphasize the importance of sufficient training when incorporating new factual information.
<1793575970202652872> questions the criteria for choosing between fine-tuning and retraining an LLM, using the example of adapting a model trained on Anglo-Saxon law to French law.
<1791398204119851051> raises the concern that fine-tuning might introduce hallucinations by over-optimizing for new knowledge, suggesting empirical investigation.

Other discussions touch upon the technical nuances of pre-training and fine-tuning, such as the role of learning rate and data distribution. <1791198938852110652> asks about catastrophic forgetting during fine-tuning and the need to incorporate pre-training data.
How harmful are unknown examples?: <1791131136128590218> questioned the paper's contradiction with other works on fine-tuning and new knowledge. <1791927719023804823> clarified that the paper doesn't deny new knowledge acquisition but highlights the slow learning and increased hallucination tendency.

<1791126233511555122> pointed out the discrepancy between this paper's findings and other fine-tuning research like Llema. <1791135639888376111> questioned the high epoch count (50) used for fine-tuning.
Other discussions touched upon the slow learning of new facts and the correlation between the proportion of unknown examples and overfitting.
Unknown examples are fitted slower than: <1793346041841848448> asked why fine-tuning large language models struggles to introduce new knowledge compared to pre-training, and hypothesized that it might be due to the relative quantity of data used in fine-tuning being smaller than that in pre-training.

Introduction: The authors explored how new knowledge introduced during fine-tuning affects LLMs' tendency to hallucinate. <1789185269586878703> shared past experiences of fine-tuning failures when incorporating new knowledge, echoing the paper's findings.

<1790401515670143009> suggested that modern fine-tuning acts more like meta-learning, focusing on using existing skills, which aligns with the paper's conclusion about leveraging pre-existing knowledge.
<1793319242466812364> highlighted the conflict between fitting response formats and the lack of trained knowledge, potentially explaining the observed hallucinations.
How harmful are unknown examples?: <1791126224594489766> suggests that fine-tuning on new knowledge can negatively impact model performance unless the quality of the new data is carefully curated.

<1789226347086135589> explains that incorporating new knowledge requires the model to adjust its weights, potentially leading to suboptimal performance without proper validation. <1789226350743589025> adds that this increases the risk of the model diverging from its original training.
<1793965243888226337> interprets the findings by suggesting that LLMs prioritize sounding true over being factually accurate, and fine-tuning exacerbates this tendency.
Understanding knowledge types: their val: <1791175854875185441> found it intriguing that training LLMs on "maybe known" samples can improve knowledge retrieval, despite the paper's main finding that fine-tuning new knowledge might increase hallucinations.
Discussion: <1794019096998154646> wondered if a model trained on learning knowledge could be used to train another model for specialization.

<1841786268776104244> expressed concern about increased hallucinations in fine-tuned models, relating it to human learning. <1841815210958438471> clarified that hallucinations may not be solely due to forgetting, referencing the paper's appendix.

Related work: <1793332538292810018> shared a video summary [[youtu.be/p7xQRIHWG_M?si…]] that provides further context and interpretation of the paper's findings regarding the relationship between fine-tuning, new knowledge acquisition, and hallucinations in LLMs.
General: <1791908453134520730> and <1795401294196416783> provided a link to the paper on arXiv [[arxiv.org/abs/2405.05904]], which allows readers to access the full text and further investigate the research.

Study setup: <1788981375040676036> points out a significant gap in the paper: while "fine-tuning" is mentioned frequently, the specific algorithm used is not described.

Related work: <1791170749245554902> highlighted their previous research on LLM sycophancy, which found that training on new knowledge can lead to unpredictable behaviors, corroborating the paper's findings on hallucinations.

<1878618042235506788> mentioned that Section 7 in "arxiv.org/pdf/2405.05904" [[arxiv.org/pdf/2405.05904]] explores how SFT can improve a model's ability to express uncertainty, potentially increasing accuracy by training it to say "I don't know."

<1789065788433064314> shared "arxiv.org/pdf/2404.11018" [[arxiv.org/pdf/2404.11018]], a study that observed increased hallucinations with large context windows in MSL, offering a different perspective on the issue.

Q&A.Introduction: The authors investigate how introducing new factual knowledge during fine-tuning affects LLMs' tendency to hallucinate. They propose a method to categorize knowledge and conduct a controlled study on question answering, finding that learning new facts is slow and can lead to hallucinations, especially in later training stages.
Q&A.How harmful are unknown examples?: The authors investigated how fine-tuning LLMs with new knowledge affects hallucinations. They varied the proportion of unknown examples in the training data and observed that higher proportions led to slower learning and increased overfitting, especially after 50 epochs.  Test performance was used as a proxy for hallucinations.
Q&A.Unknown examples are fitted slower than: The authors found that large language models fit known information faster than unknown information during fine-tuning.  This suggests that fine-tuning primarily helps models expose pre-existing knowledge rather than acquire new factual knowledge.

Perspective.Introduction: The authors investigated how introducing new factual knowledge during fine-tuning affects large language models. They found that LLMs learn new facts slower than pre-existing ones and that incorporating new knowledge can lead to increased hallucinations, suggesting fine-tuning primarily improves the use of existing knowledge.
Perspective.How harmful are unknown examples?: The authors investigated the impact of fine-tuning LLMs with new knowledge. They found that incorporating new knowledge can lead to overfitting and reduced performance, especially when the new information is a significant portion of the training data.  This is because the model prioritizes fitting the new data, potentially at the expense of retaining previously learned knowledge.
Perspective.Understanding knowledge types: their val: The authors explored how different degrees of known facts, categorized as HighlyKnown, MaybeKnown, and WeaklyKnown, affect large language models' (LLMs) knowledge integration and hallucination during fine-tuning.  They found that training on MaybeKnown samples, facts LLMs are less certain about, surprisingly enhances knowledge retrieval.
Perspective.Discussion: The authors explored whether fine-tuning large language models (LLMs) on new knowledge encourages hallucinations. They found a correlation between acquiring new knowledge through fine-tuning and hallucinations related to pre-existing knowledge.  They also discussed the implications for fine-tuning practices and the superficial alignment hypothesis.

Critique.Study setup: The authors explore how fine-tuning large language models (LLMs) with new knowledge affects their tendency to generate incorrect information (hallucinations). They use a dataset of questions and answers based on Wikidata facts to control the new knowledge introduced to the LLM.
